results.title: Seeing red: stories of American communists
results.creator_credit: James Klein, Julia Reichert and Heartland Productions
results.brief_description: Compelling Academy Award-nominated documentary providing an oral history account of the American Communist Party from the Great Depression, through McCarthyist demonisation of the 50s, to the early 80s. Employing a wealth of archival material culled from over 400 interview sessions with former and current party members, the film provides a vernacular account of the American Left. Includes footage of speeches made by Ronald Reagan, Richard Nixon, Hubert Humphrey and Joseph McCarthy set the context for the film. The film provides a fascinating vernacular account of the American Left.

results.title: Seeing red and feeling blue
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Provides basic information about reproduction and aspects of menstruation, and probes emotional responses on many aspects of womanhood. The Women’s Theatre Group of Melbourne performs improvisations and satirical sketches which comment on many of society’s prevailing attitudes towards sex education and women.

results.title: Seeds of discovery
results.creator_credit: Bert Lawrence, National Aeronautics and Space Administration and MRC Films
results.brief_description: An introduction to planetary exploration and scientific satellite research considered for the 1970’s. Briefly describes plans for Mariner flybys of Mars, Pioneer studies of Jupiter, landings of unmanned Viking spacecraft on Mars, a grand tour of the outer planets, and solar and other astronomy research.

results.title: Will the Great Barrier Reef cure Claude Clough
results.creator_credit: John Milson, Richard Mason and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A travel film with a difference. Claude Clough, frustrated and depressed, consults a psychiatrist who prescribes a holiday on the Great Barrier Reef. Underwater photography shows some of the dazzling coral formations and reefs and the striking scenery of the reef islands. A satirical fantasy on the theme of a holiday on the Great Barrier Reef.

results.title: Will you answer true? (NP)
results.brief_description: A companion film to “When I’m calling you”. John Cleese demonstrates an object lesson in how not to handle a sales inquiry on the telephone. Demonstrates eight points of correct telephone sales techniques to turn a general inquiry into a firm order. Narrated by Andrew Sachs. Cast includes John Cleese, Norman Bird, April Walker, Penelope Keith.

results.title: Wildness
results.creator_credit: Bill Murphy, Scott Millwood, Michael McMahon, Big and Little Films and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Tasmanian landscape photographers Olegas Truchanas and Peter Dombrovskis had much in common. Born 22 years apart both came from Baltic Europe and migrated to Tasmania, where they developed a passion for visiting and photographing the island’s remote, wild places. Both men died before their time in the wilderness doing what they loved, and left a legacy of stunning landscape and nature photography which became synonymous with campaigns to protect Tasmania’s natural heritage. They believed that if people could see the beauty of Australia’s wild places then they might be moved to save them. Through the sixties and seventies Truchanas raised public awareness about the beauty and uniqueness of the Tasmanian wilderness, and the threat to it posed by the Tasmanian government’s massive hydro-electric schemes, through his now legendary slide presentations. After his death his work was carried on by Dombrovskis who published his images in calendars and allowed them to be used freely in the successful campaign to save the Franklin River from hydro-electric development. Combining interviews and archival footage with over 300 photographs by Truchanas and Dombrowskis, ‘Wildness’ is an accomplished tribute to the two men’s invaluable contribution to both visual culture and environmental awareness in Australia. Narrated by Nina Landis. Teachers notes are available from the Film Australia website. [www.filmaust.com.au]

results.title: Formal gardens
results.creator_credit: Bruce Franchini, Stuart Crowner and Perennial Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Gardens of the world”.
Audrey Hepburn travels through the rich evolution of formal garden design in some of the world’s most spectacular settings - from the Renaissance gardens of Italy, (Villa Gamberaia, Villa Lante, Villa La Pietra), the grand 17th century gardens of France, (Chateau de Courances, Versailles), to the lushly planted gardens of England, (Hidcote Manor, Tintinhull House). Narrated by Michael York.

results.title: Public gardens and trees
results.creator_credit: Bruce Franchini, Stuart Crowner and Perennial Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Gardens of the world”.
Host Audrey Hepburn explores the beautifully restored gardens at Mt. Vernon, originally created for the private pleasures of one of America’s first great gardeners, George Washington. This garden stands today as one of America’s most charming public gardens. Audrey Hepburn presents the diversity and wealth of public gardens in the city of Paris, among them, intimate ‘pocket-parks’, former grand royal gardens and spectacular pleasure gardens. Narrated by Michael York.

results.title: Flower gardens
results.creator_credit: Bruce Franchini, Stuart Crowner and Perennial Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Gardens of the world”.
Perhaps no garden in the world exhibits a more exhilirating use of flowers than Claude Monet’s garden at Giverny. Monet’s exuberant palette of colours strikingly contrasts with the grace and elegance of the classic perennial borders found at Tintinhull House in Somerset, England. The native flora of America’s southeast further illustrate the range of aesthetics and pleasure found in the world’s most beautiful flower gardens. Hosted by Audrey Hepburn and narrated by Michael York.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Franchini, Stuart Crowner and Perennial Productions

results.title: Tulips and spring bulbs
results.creator_credit: Bruce Franchini, Stuart Crowner and Perennial Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Gardens of the world”.
The vast, colourful bulb fields of our host audrey Hepburn’s native Holland are only a small part of a complex cultural phenomenon. Here bulbs are intertwined with the history and art of an entire country. The transformation from sleeping bulb to elegant bloom is miraculous. Narcissus, hyacinth, muscari and bluebells share the stage with the favourite, the tulip, for a grand tour of the spectacular Kreukenhof in Holland and Chenics Manor, in England and more. Hosted by Audrey Hepburn and narrated by Michael York.
